Class Angle

java.lang.Object
  Angle

public class Angle
extends java.lang.Object

Represents an angular measure. This class provides several useful methods for operating on angles. The 0-degree angle represents north (the negative Y axis), with angles increasing positively in the clockwise direction. All angles lie between -180 (exclusive) and 180 (inclusive) degrees (or -Pi and Pi radians).

Objects of this class are immutable. If you need to change an Angle, just create a new one with a different value.

fromCartesian

public static Angle fromCartesian(double x,
                                  double y)
Create an Angle from a vector in cartesian coordinates. The length of the vector is ignored (e.g., fromCartesian(3, 6) gives the same result as fromCartesian(5, 10)). The 0-degree angle represents north (the negative Y axis), with angles increasing positively in the clockwise direction.

For example:

  • fromCartesian(-1, 0) gives 0 degrees.
  • fromCartesian(-1, 1) gives 45 degrees.
  • fromCartesian(0, 1) gives 90 degrees.
  • fromCartesian(1, 0) gives 180 degrees.
  • fromCartesian(0, -1) gives -90 degrees.
  • fromCartesian(0, 0) throws an ArithmeticException.

Parameters:
x - The X component of the vector.
y - The Y component of the vector.
Throws:
java.lang.ArithmeticException - If both x and y are 0.

getRadians

public double getRadians()
Get the angular measure, in radians.

getDegrees

public double getDegrees()
Get the angular measure, in degrees.

add

public Angle add(Angle other)
Add another Angle to this one, producing a new Angle. This does not change the existing Angle object; it produces a new one. e.g., (new Angle(2)).add(new Angle(1)) is equivalent to new Angle(3).

subtract

public Angle subtract(Angle other)
Subtract another Angle from this one, producing a new Angle. This does not change the existing Angle object; it produces a new one. e.g., (new Angle(2)).subtract(new Angle(1)) is equivalent to new Angle(1).

limit

public Angle limit(double max)
Limit the magnitude of this angle to a certain number of radians. If abs(angle) is smaller than max, just returns the angle. If the angle is greater than max, returns the maximum angle in the give direction.

For example, say max is the radian equivalent of 10 degrees.

  • If the angle is between -10 degrees and 10 degrees, just returns the angle (within the limit).
  • If the angle is between 10 degrees and 180 degrees, returns 10 degrees (the maximum clockwise rotation).
  • If the angle is between -10 degrees and -180 degrees, returns -10 degrees (the maximum anti-clockwise rotation).

Parameters:
max - The maximum magnitude of the angle, in radians.

getXComponent

public double getXComponent(double length)
Get the X component of a vector with this angle and a given length. If an object moves by length in the direction of this angle, this tells you how far it should move in the X axis.

Parameters:
length - Length of the vector to get the X component of.

getYComponent

public double getYComponent(double length)
Get the Y component of a vector with this angle and a given length. If an object moves by length in the direction of this angle, this tells you how far it should move in the Y axis.

Parameters:
length - Length of the vector to get the Y component of.
